hints_html: If a function is differentiable at \(a\), must it also be continuous at \(a\)?
hints_latex:
If a function is differentiable at $a$, must it also be continuous at
$a$?
hints_raw: If a function is differentiable at <math>a</math>, must it also be continuous at <math>a</math>?
question: 1 (l)
sols_html:
If \(f\) is differentiable at a, then \(f\) must also be continuous at a. Hence, the limit

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to a} f(x)\end{aligned}\]

exists and is equal to \(f\)(a). The correct answer is therefore B.
sols_latex:
If $f$ is differentiable at \emph{a}, then $f$ must also be continuous at
\emph{a}. Hence, the limit

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x\to a} f(x)
\end{align*}

exists and is equal to $f$\emph{(a)}. The correct answer is therefore
\textbf{B}.
